* Erik Wilde <dret@...> [2015-06-17 11:55]:
> > On Jun 17, 2015, at 11:02, Aristotle Pagaltzis pagaltzis@... wrote:
> > * kalguni@... [2015-06-17 03:40]:
> > > I read lots of articles on these. Yet it seems to be more of
> > > a personal choice rather than an Industry standard.
> >
> > It is personal choice. As far as REST is concerned, you can use
> > GUIDs as your URLs for all the difference it makes. Of course, in
> > practice “REST API” is code for “HTTP/RPC hybrid” and not at all
> > a hypermedia- driven design, but even so, it’s up to you. It’s
> > essentially similar to naming functions or methods – there *is* bad
> > design and bad ideas, but there is no correctness criterion.
>
> only because it's misused and misinterpreted in many places doesn't
> mean it isn't well-defined, or that you cannot do it right or do it
> wrong. many REST labels are simply wrongly assigned for marketing
> reasons, but at least on this list we should know better and not tell
> people that it's essentially meaningless. it's not, and getting it
> right or not makes a difference in practice.

Only because it’s misused and misinterpreted everywhere doesn’t mean
that’s not worth stating. You can do it well or badly but not right or
wrong. On this list we should know better than to confuse “meaningless
to the client in a hypermedia design” with “meaningless in its essence”.
And unless you also thought I was championing the use of GUIDs as method
names I don’t know why after I said it’s akin to naming your methods or
your CSS classes you would think I was saying it makes no difference in
practice.
